data.text:
Pages

description Page 1

Englands CHRONICLE: OR, The Lives and Reigns of all the Kings and Queens, from the time of JÆ²LIÆ²S CAESAR, to the present Reign of K. William & Qu. Mary, &c.

A Discription of the Island of Britain, with its Original Denomination, &c.

THE Island of Great Britain, whose Fame has travel'd with the Sun, and reached the remotest Kingdoms of the Earth, is bounded with Germany and Denmark on the East, or properly with the German Ocian, on the West with Ireland, or the Irish Seas on the North, with the Ducalidonian Seas; and on the South, with France and Normandy, scituate in the eighth Climate of the North Latitude, and placed in relation to Longitude between the Parrals of fourteen and sixteen, Containing in length from Strathy-Head in the Kingdom of Scotland, to the Lizard point in Cornâ£wal, Six Hundred Twenty Four Miles, and in Breadth, from the Isle of Thannet in Kent, to the Lands end in Cernwal, Three Hundred and Forty Miles, though forâ£merly its Limits were Fancied from the Orcadâ¢â¢s, to the ãâ¦ããâ¦ã Mountainâ¢â¢

description Page 2

As for the time of its being peopled, (even the most curious Historians vary) some hold it to be inhabited long before the Flood, and that being a part of France, it was by the Rapid Inundation of the Universe, broken off from the Continent, where now the Channel parts Dover from Calais; and by that means, being left by the Flood, became an Island: But this I conceive only conjectural, without any warrantable Testimony; and is grounded upon the Pariety of the Soils, and Temâ£prature of Air. Since that, there are others that will have it possessed by one Albion a Gyant, who beat out the Samotheans, whose Gigantick Race increased till the time that King Brute, Coasting these Seas with a powre of Trojans under his Command, observing its spaciousness and fertility, made a Descent, and subâ£dued it; and of this latter Opinion, is the so much Ceâ£lebrate Antiquary and Historian, Jeffry of Monmouth; and from this Trojan Prince he would have us believe, the Island took its Name: But those, who have seriâ£ously enquired into the Date, he proposes for the Landâ£ing of Brute, viz. In the 2887 Year of the worlds Creation, find not any Foundation to Build a belief, that such a Man was ever in these Parts; but rather the Name was derived from the word Prith or Brith, signifying Painting, and probably the Greeks, who were then the greatest Navigators, Sailing along the Coast, and perceiving the painted People that inhabited it, might, from that signification, give it a Name, as inâ£deed they did to most Islands and Countries, that were not Civilized, where ever they came; or it might be from the word ã in non-Latin alphabet ãã in non-Latin alphabet ãMettals, for its abounâ£ding with Mettals, as it had done that of Albion, from Albis Rupibus, viz. White Rocks, that appear towards the Coast of France.

These are the Conjecturals, and we might run on in a maze of uncertainty, till we tired the Reader; conâ£sidering, that, before the Landing of the Romans, thâ¢â¢ People were uncivilized, keeping no Writings or Râ¢â¢ cords of their Country or Actions, to Druids or Priests

description Page 3

themselves being a kind of Magicians, or such as dealt in Spells and Charms, preserving their Religious Rites and Ceremonies in Hieroglipicks and Figures, after the manner of Egypt, the better to create an Awe and Dread upon the more ignorant, and raise an esteem and veneâ£ration of themselves, which otherwise must have much abated the Credit they had gained: But leaving things that are doubtful, and have never been fully cleared by the most curious and industrious Writers, we come to what is more warrantable, and for what we have sureâ¢â¢ grounds (laying aside the Story of the Samothes, sprung from the ãâããâã Son of Japhat, perhaps as Fabulous as the rest) and that is to the Year of the Worlds Creatiâ£on, 3873. Viz.

Caius Julius Caesar, by the prevailing Arms of the Roman Commonwealth, having subdued Gallia, now France, and a great part of Germany, thirsty of new Glory, by Conquest, being invited hither by Andragiâ£us, one of the Sons of King Lud, upon a Quarrel that happened between him and his Uncle Cassibelan. King of the Trinobantes, he, from the Shoars of Gallia, viewâ£ing the Coast, and finding, by Report and Scituation, that it was fair and fruitful, in a temperate Climate; and that its Conquest would highly redound to his Honour, and the Advantage of the Roman People, he setled, as well as the shortness of the time, would permit the new Conquests, and prepared an extraordâ¢â¢â£nery Fleet of Ships, and smaller Vessels, for the Transâ£portation of his Army; yet had he much ado to makâ¢â¢ the Legions Imberque, who perceiving the dreadful Rocks on the distant Shore, together with the roughâ£ness and danger of the Sea, complained, That after all the Toiles and Hardships they had indured, he was now aâ£bout to carry them into another World; for so they esteeâ£med this great Island.

Caesar, notwithstanding the speed that attended his Expeditions, was not so silent in his Preparation, but the Britains had notice of it from such of the Gauis, as had made their escapes in small Barques; and upon his atâ£tempting

description Page 4

to land, he found the Shores between Dover and Sandwich covered with the armed Britains, under Casibâ¢â¢lan and other Kings, who disputed his landing with great resolution and sury, beating him twice from the Shore, with the loss of his Sword, and the no small danger of his Person, which constrained him to put his Archers on board small Vessels, whose Shot (to which the Britains were not accustomed) made them retire, whilst under that Favour he landed part of his Legions, yet long was it before he could make good his ground, with the loss of his huge Fleet broken to pieces by the fury of the Tempest, and a great number of his Men slain in divers Conflicts and Skirmishes, for the Natives sighting partly in hook-armed Waggons, or their faâ£shion'd Chariots of War, and partly on foot with Spears, small imboss'd Shields, and large Swords, being exceeâ£ding nimble, charged and retired in Parties as they saw it convenient, and when in any Battel they were worâ£sted, they betook themselves to fortified Woods, which served them in the nature of Castles: So that in the end this great Conquerour, tired with continual Alarums, thought it convenient to make a Peace with those Kings that had opposed him, and taking Hostages, he returned to France, there to quiet some new Commotions that were arisen.

The People, in the condition Casar found them, were tall, big-bodied, strong, and greatly addicted to hardship, having few Towns, unless such as were the Capitals of their Kings, but lived in fortified Woods, the Men being allowed as many Wives as they could keep, fierce and cruel, yet sparing in Dyet, and not much adâ£dicted to Labour, so that the Ground lay mostly untilâ£led; and when they sowed their Corn, they only strewâ£ed it on the Earth, and harrowed it over with Bushes, on which they laid considerable weights; and being carried away with a notion of the Pythagorians, they forâ£bore very much to kill or destroy the Creatures lest they should unhouse the Souls of their Friends and nearest Relations, which they concluded at their deaths had

description Page 5

passed by Transmigration into them; so that Hares, Hens, and Geese especially, were found in such plenty, and so same, that it was admirable, with great store of delicious Fruits, which Nature of her own accord had produced.

The Trade of the Britains, if any abroad, was very inconsiderable; for, as Casar observes, their Boats were for the most part Leather drawn over Wicker of Osiers, or such as were fewed together with Thongs, so that they durst not venture far from the shore, nor did they trouble themselves with any store of Provision when they Sailed. The better sort were clad, but they mostâ£ly with Skins, which they had not the art to dress; taking a ãâããâã of pride in Nakedness, for as much as beâ£ing Young, they Raised and Sâ¢â¢arrified their Skins into Carved Works, of Bâ¢â¢rds, Bâ¢â¢asls, Trâ¢â¢es, Flowers, Fist, Sunâ¢â¢, Mconâ¢â¢, Sâ¢â¢rs, and the like; it bâ¢â¢ing a Trade oâ¢â¢ Imployment, to persons well versed in iâ¢â¢ as well as Paiâ¢â¢ting or Carving at this Day; and in there Sears they suppled the Juice of Would or Woâ¢â¢d, which not only couloâ¢â¢red their Bodâ¢â¢â¢â¢, ãâããâã sinking in where the Skin gave way, left a lasting Stain that grew up with them to Maturity, fortifying their Bodys by shutting up the ãâããâã against heat or cold; and though they lived in a sind of a state of Innocency, sequâ¢â¢stered from the hurâ£ry and business of more Civiliz'd Mations, yet being under many Governours, they frequently Wared upâ£on each other through Emulation; though their Riches were inconsidâ¢â¢rable, their Coyn, or what was Courant amongst them, being only Brass or Irsn, Ringâ¢â¢, Boxes, Oâ¢â¢nches, at a certain Sieze or Weight, though afterward, by the Example of the Romans, they stamped Silver and Gold, with sundry Devices, Imbosâ¢â¢ Shield ways. They made their Drink of Barly, boiled in Water, but took little account of Milk, and less of their Cattle, taking great pride in shaving themselves all but the upâ£per Lip, which they did in imitation of the Gauls, wearing Iron Chains about their Necks and Wasts, with Brass Rings on their Fingers, as Ornaments; and

description Page 6

they had Women in common, amongst Brothers and Parents, and the Issue was attributed to him who first gathered her Virginity.

As for the Religion of the Antient Britains (if so I may term it, and not rather a Diabolieaâ¢â¢ Delusion) it was Superstitious and Barbarous for the Druids or Priests, whom they held to be very Oracles, gave themâ£selves up to Witchcrasts and Inchantments, mutteâ£ring horrid Charms, pretending to raise Stoâ¢â¢ms and Tempests, to call for Lightning and Thunder: Nor was their Idolatry less, for they had Images, almost without number, to which they prayed, and made Sacrifice under certain Names and Figures, as the Priests directed, not sparing to offer the Flesh of their Enemies taken in War, and amongst them, even Priest-craft reigned in those days; for Excommunicaâ£tion was of great Force, and the Theologie they held, was, that the Soul being Immortal, lost not, nor lesâ£sened in its Existence by the dying of the Body, but passed in its Existence by the dying of the Body, but passed into another, either rational or irrational Creaâ£ture, and their Pxiests were Judges in all Civil Controâ£versies.

This was the state of the Britains, when the Romans same first acquainted with the Island and those of Enâ£gland, so named since that time, from a place in Denâ£mark called Engelon, or from the East Augles, were diâ£stinguished by their Cantons or Tribes, in the following order and possession, viz. The Cantij possessed Kent; the Regni, Sâ¢â¢ssex and Surry; the Durotriges, Dorset-shire; the Damnoni, Devon-shire and Cornwal; the Belgâ¢â¢e, Somerâ£set-shire, Wilt-shire, and Sonthampton-shire; the Atrebati, Bark-shire; the Dubuni, Oxford-shire and Glocester-shire; the Catieuclani, Warwick-shire, Buckingham-shire, and â¢â¢edford-shire; the Trinobantes, Hartford-shire, Essex, and Middl sex; the Icenij, Suffolk, Norfolk, Cambridge-shire and Huntington-shire, the Conitani, Lincoln-shire, Rutlandâ£shâ¢â¢re, Northampton-shire, Leicester-shire, Dâ¢â¢rby-shire, and Nottingham-shire; the Cornaby, Stafford-shire, Worcester-shire, Cheshire, and Shropshire.

description Page 7

The Cantons of Wales had likewise their order and division, viz. The Ordovices possessed Flintshire, Carâ£narvan-shire, Denby-shire, Mountgomery-shire, and Meâ£rionoth-shire; the Silures Hereford-shire, Radnor-shire, Brecknock, Monmouth, and Glamorgan-shire; The Dimetâ¢â¢e Carâ¢â¢marden-shire, Pembrook-shire, and Carâ£digan-shire; the Ottodini & Brigantes Parisi were accounâ£ted separate from the former, and possessed themselves of York-shire, Lancashire, Durham, Richmond, Counâ£ty Westmorland, Cumberland, Northâ¢â¢mberland; and the latter, sometimes of March, Teifidale, Twâ¢â¢edale and Louthian: These Divisions had their respective Heads or Governours, to whom they made Acknowledgment, and payed some inconsiderable Tribute; though most of that kind fell to the share of the Priests; and indeed their Riches was but small, for Cesar, when he found he had a considerable Advantage over the Southren part of this Island, layed no greater Tax upon them, than three hundred pounds a year, as a Tributary Acknowâ£ledgment to Rome: We might insist on the Tribes that were possessed of Scotland, and the Island, belonging to Great Britain, but not being much to the purpose, it is convenient to pursue the more materialpart of History.

This part of Great Britain, is the most plentiful, aâ£bounding with all Things necessary for the pleasure and Support of Humane Life, and was named (as is said) England, from Englone, a place in Denmark; or as some will have it, from a People, called East Angles, who placed themselves in the Eastern part of it, in the time of the Saxons; which name, neither the Danes nor Norâ£mans, in their Conquests, thought fit to Change or Alâ£ter; so that it contained it for the space of eight hunâ£dred seventy three years, when King James united it with Scotland, 1602. and restored the Ancient Name of Great Britain; and such Reputation it all along had, aâ¢â¢ to gain the fifth place in General Councils, and was stiled (for the abundance of Plenty it afforded, to Supply the Neighbour Nation) the Store-house of the Western world, for from henâ¢â¢s, even in early days,

description Page 8

the Romans were wont yearly to Lade eight hundred Vesâ£sels with Corn, for the supply of their Armies in other Countries; so that it has been often taken for the Forâ£tunate Island, mentioned by antient Wâ¢â¢iters, especiâ£ally the Grâ¢â¢cians: But above all, it has been the pecuâ£liar Care of Heaven, in that the Christian Faith was planted here, in the sixty third year of our Sâ¢â¢viours Inâ£carnation; and it is held (not without good groundâ¢â¢) that Josâ¢â¢ph of Aramathca, was sent hither by Philip, the Apostle of France, and that he was Buried at Glâ¢â¢ssâ¢â¢nbury; and some will have it, and shew much Reason for it, that St. Paul was here, and Preached the Gospel: Howâ£ever, this is certain, It enjoyed the first Christian King, in the person of King Lucius, and gave birth to that Glorious Propagator of Christianity, Constantine, the great Emperor of Rome: But thus much for History in General, from whence we proceed to what is more particular.

Thus Fame, to breath our Nations Glory's proud: Hark! How her Golden Trumpet sounds aloud! From Pole to Pole, the Mighty â¢â¢lasâ¢â¢ is gone, To fill all Nationâ¢â¢, circl'd by the ãâããâã.

An Historical Account of the British Princes, that opposen the Romans, in their attempting to Settle in thâ¢â¢se parts.

THE Romans, under Casar, first taking the Advanâ£tage of the Divisions and Animosities, riegning amongst the petty Princes of the Britains, made no oâ£ther account, but to Gain a full Possession, with little trouble or hazard; but found themselves mistaken, eâ£ven in barbarous Valour, as they Termed it; for so it fell out, That King Lud, who built the Wâ¢â¢st-Gate of the City of London; and was the first Founder of the City it self, calling it Carelud, tho' not in extent, as at present, dying, and leaving two Sonâ¢â¢, viz. Andragius and Tâ¢â¢mantius, their Uncle Cassibelane (by the Fathers

description Page 9

direction) took upon him the Government, till they should be of Age, stiling himself Prince of the Trinâ¢â¢â£bants, or new Troy, as some will have it; being the most powerful of all the Princes of the Britains, and when his Nephews were capable of Rule, he gave to Andragius Trinovant, the Dukedom of Kent; and to Temantius the Dukedom of Cornwal, reserving to himself the City of Verilum, now St. Albons, and other â¢â¢ependances: But Andragius being dissatisfied with his Uncle, and hearing the Fame of Caesars great Actions, â¢â¢mplored his Assistance against him; and so far preâ£vailed, that he came over, and Overcame this Prince, after a long and obstinate Resistance, wherein eighty thousand were slain on both sides, at sundry times, and the Country's Amerced for breaking the Truce; and when he left the Island, Andragius, with a great many British Souldiers, went along with him, to help him in his Wars against Pompey the Great, whom he Overâ£threw in the Pharsalian Fields. So that, after the death of Cassibelan, who expired at York: Temantius possessed both his Father's and Uncle's Dominions; nor had Caesar only this Prince to Contend with, but likeâ£wise Cingitorix, Taximagul, and Caravil, petty Kings of Kent; but his Fortune prevailing against them, their Men slain, and they routed; the first was taken, and the two last fled: So that the Roman Arms growing dreadful to the rest of the Princes, after they had lent what Assistance they could, and found themselves too weak to Oppose a prevailing Conqueror, Senimagues, Ancalites, Bibroses, and the rest of the States of Icenij laid down their Arms, and submitted, as did many oâ£thers: However, Câ¢â¢esar rather shewed the Romans this Island, than subdued it, or knew the Extent of it; for neither by Arms, or Intelligence, could he discover, whether it was an Island, or Continent.

Caesar, (after having waded through the World, at a Sea of Blood, and reached the very Pinacle of huâ£mane Greatness) being slain in the Senate House in Rome, by the Conspiracy of the Senators; Augustus

description Page 10

Caesar coming to the Imperial Throne, the Britains bâ¢â¦â¢â¦â£gan to bethink themselves of casting off the Romaâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Yoke, under Cunobeline, who held his Regal Seat â¢â¦â¢â¦ Malden in Essex, and had been Kinghted by Julius Gâ¢â¦â¢â¦â£sar; and indeed they went a great way in it; Aâ¢â¦â¢â¦â£gustus prepared three times, utterly to Subdue him, an his Dominions, but was diverted by other Affairs: â¢â¦â¢â¦ that in the twenty third Year of this King's Reign, thâ¢â¦â¢â¦ PRINCE of Peace, our Blessed Lord and Saviour, beinâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Born, the Lyon lay down with the Lamb: An Universâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Peace ensued, according as it had been foretold bâ¢â¦â¢â¦ the Prophets. This was the first of the British King that stamped his Image upon his Coyn; and Dying fulâ¢â¦â¢â¦ of years, he was succeeded by Guiderius his Son, whâ¢â¦â¢â¦ was no less desirous than his Father, to shake off thâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Roman Tribute: When he heard Augustus Câ¢â¦â¢â¦sar waâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Dead: and Caligula, who was Emperor in his steadâ¢â¦â¢â¦ being denied the Payment, made great preparation against him, but being an Emperor of little Conduct, anâ¢â¦â¢â¦ less Courage; coming to the Belgick shore, he made hâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Souldiers gather Shells in their Helmets, whilst thâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Trumpets sounded a Charge, as to the Battle, and â¢â¦â¢â¦ returned in a foolish kind of Triumph, proud to haâ¢â¦â¢â¦ taken the Spoils of the Ocean; but Claudius Drusius, whâ¢â¦â¢â¦ succeeded him, overthrew Guiderius, and his Britain under the Conduct of his Deputy; and in the Fighâ¢â¦â¢â¦ the King was slain by the Treachery of one Hamo, whâ¢â¦â¢â¦ (pretending friendship) in a Disguise got near his Peâ¢â¦â¢â¦ son; but being pursued by Arviragus, the King's Bâ¢â¦â¢â¦â£ther, to the shore of the Sea, himself was there diâ¢â¦â¢â¦â£patched, from whose Fall some Antiquaries affirâ¢â¦â¢â¦ the Place took the Name of Hamo's Haven, now tâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Town of Southampton.

The Father and Son thus Dead, Catacratus, a secoâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Son to Cunobeline, assumed the Throne; when followâ£ing his Predecessors, in opposing the Romans, he was a great and mortal Battle, overthrown with the loss almost all his People; and himself being taken Priâ¢â¦â¢â¦â£ner, was carried to Rome, where he was led throuâ¢â¦â¢â¦

description Page 11

â¢â¦â¢â¦he streets in a triumph of Derision, to honour Aulus â¢â¦â¢â¦lautinus his Conqueror; yet Togodumnuis the third â¢â¦â¢â¦on of Cunobeline, succeeded him, but with as bad forâ£â¢â¦â¢â¦une; for after he had harazed their Camp, and slain many of them, in such a manner, that Plautinus was obliged to send for the Emperor Drâ¢â¦â¢â¦sius, who â¢â¦â¢â¦rought with him a great Power, a Mortal Battle was â¢â¦â¢â¦ought, in which the British King was slain; yet Arâ£â¢â¦â¢â¦iragus, the last of the Brothers, had leave to Succeed â¢â¦â¢â¦im; and he, for a while, held a fair Correspondency with the Romans, but finding his opportunity fell off, â¢â¦â¢â¦nd joyning with some petty Neighbours, gave the â¢â¦â¢â¦mperor such Apprehensions of Danger, that he â¢â¦â¢â¦hought it best for his Repose, and the Securing the Roman Interest in this Island, to give him his Daughâ£er Genissa in Marriage. This Assinity calmed Affairs for a time, and the Britains having learned the Roman Customes, became much civilized, forgetting their Barbarous Nature, cloathing themselves, and building Houses; so that the Island extreamly Flourished, and â¢â¦â¢â¦ested from War, during the Life of Arviragus, and was very little troubled in the time of Cogidâ¢â¦â¢â¦nus: But Characticus, a Prince of the Silures, growing poâ£werful, by the contracted Forces of his Neighbours, drew into the Field, and beat the Roman Souldiers from their Strenghts, making great Slaughter of them; yet in the end, being Overthrown, he fled to Cartâ¢â¦â¢â¦smandua for shelter and protection; but she, desirous to ingraâ£tiate her self with the Emperor, caused him, contraâ£ty to her Faith plighted, to be delivered up to his Eneâ£mies, who, the better to keep their new Acquiessitions in Peace, sont him to Rome, where, beholding the Magnificence of that Luxurant City, he reproved the Roman Covetousness and Ambition, saying, He admâ¢â¦â¢â¦â£red, that they, being Master, of such glorâ¢â¦â¢â¦ous Tâ¢â¦â¢â¦mples, Structures, and Riches, should nevertheâ¢â¢â¢â¢ss crave after the Cottages, and poor Possâ¢â¦â¢â¦ssions of the Britains: And altho' this Prince was removed, another stood up in his stead, Prâ¢â¦â¢â¦sutagus King of the Icenij; yet

description Page 12

finding himself in no good Condition to Resist, hâ¢â¦â¢â¦ made Peace, and growing near his end, left Queeâ¢â¦â¢â¦-Boduo, and his two Daughters, in the Protection of the Emperor Nero, whom he had made his Heir; but the Ladies being of Incomparable Beauty, and contrary to the Trust reposed, Ravished; the valiant Queen calâ£led together her Friends and Commanders, acquainâ£ting them with the Treachery, and desiring their assistance, telling them, That the Romans were infebleâ¢â¦â¢â¦ by Ease and Luxury; and therefore being resolutely soâ¢â¦â¢â¦ upon, they would fly like a timorous Hare; and at that word (opening her Lap, she let go a Hare, which so the purpose she had concealed.

This so animated the rest, that they immediatelâ¢â¦â¢â¦ took Arms, and falling upon the Romans, in their toâ¢â¦â¢â¦ much Security, under the Conduct of this Queen, puâ¢â¦â¢â¦ eighty thousand of them to the Sword; but in the enâ¢â¦â¢â¦ New Forces arriving, she was forced to lay down her Arms, and seek for Safety: And next to he Venutius, King of the Brigantes Warred upon them but by the Trechery of his Queen, the faithless Cartâ¢â¦â¢â¦ mandua, he was Overthrown; so that the Roman having pierced into Scotland, Overthrew, in a greaâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Battle, Galgacius, Prince of the Callidonians; anâ¢â¦â¢â¦ finding none to Oppose them, they became absolutâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Masters of the Famous Island of Great Britain: Noâ¢â¦â¢â¦ was it known, that they discovered it, till this time tâ¢â¦â¢â¦ be an Island, which was about one hundred thirty six years after the Landing of Caesar, when, in a far lessâ¢â¦â¢â¦ time they Subdued all France, Germany, and otheâ¢â¦â¢â¦ Countrys insinitely larger, by which we may perâ£ceive,

The Early Valour of the British Race, Who boldly durst the worlds prou'd Conquerors Face, And put even Rome her self to soul disgrace.

description Page 13

An Historical Account of the Roman Emperors, who were personal in this Island, or Ruled by their Lieuteâ£nants.

CAius Julius Caesar (as you have heard) was the first Roman that set footing in this Island, lanâ£ding in the Year of the worlds Creation, 3873. But he did little more than show it the Romans, laying a small Tribute of 300 pounds upon it, not having passed with Armed Forces (as many hold) beyond St. Albans, then call'd Verillum, finding by the great Resistance he experienced, he had to deal with a stubborn People, over which he had no other advanâ£tage; but being better Armed, and somwhat more expert in the Trains of War; yet, after three Expeâ£ditions, he came no more; but proceeded to put the project, of gaining the Soveraignty of the World, in practice, wherein he was Successful, after the Fatal Battles of Pharsalia, Philipi, and Munda; yet his Aspiring cost him his Life, as has been Related.

Octavian Augustus Caesar, succeeded Julius, after many Troubles, and much difficulty, but came not into this Island, though he thrice intended it; and in this Golden Reign, the SAVIOUR of the World was Born: To this Great Emperor Succeeded Tiâ£berius; in the eighteenth year of whose Reign, The LORD of LIFE was put to Death, to Rise more Gâ¢â¢oâ£rious, and Triumph over Death and Hell, and the proâ£digious Defects in Nature, that attended his Passion; being obâ¢â¢erved by Dionisus Areopagita, as the Ecclipse of the Sun and Moon, &c, He cryed out, that The God of Nature suffered, or the Frame of the world was about to be dissolved: To this Emperor, Caligula Sucâ£ceeded; but the most memorable Act he did, was, the Banishing Pontius Pilate, who, thereupon, grew desperate, & Slew himself: Then came Claudius Druâ£sius, under whom, Aulus Plautinius was Deputy in Britain, who was put so hard to iâ¢â¢, that the Empeâ£ror

description Page 14

was obliged to come over; and, by the Marriâ£age of his Daughter, put an end to the Troubles Nero succeeded him in the Imperial Throne, whose wickednesses are too many to be related in this place: Amongst other things, he Crucified St. Peter, and caused St. Paul to be Beheaded, Burnt the City of Rome, Killed his Wife, Ripped up his Mother, and Perseâ£cuted the Christians with new invented Torments; he did great Injuries to the Britains, by his Lieuteâ£nants, for which Queen Boduo slew Eighty Thousand of his Romans. Sergius Galba began his Reign Anno Dom. 70.
